exercises.question: If he ___ the promotion last month, he would be working in the London office now.
exercises.answer: had accepted
exercises.example_sentence: If he had accepted the promotion last month, he would be working in the London office now.

exercises.question: Match the reporting clauses with their corresponding passive structures.
exercises.example_sentence: He is considered to be an expert in the field of linguistics.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal passive reporting sentence.
exercises.answer: The suspect is believed to be guilty
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect is believed to be guilty despite the lack of evidence.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following sentence clearly: 'If I weren't so busy this week, I would have joined you for dinner last night.'
exercises.answer: If I weren't so busy this week, I would have joined you for dinner last night.
exercises.example_sentence: If I weren't so busy this week, I would have joined you for dinner last night.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: People believe that the company is losing money.
options: The company is believed to be losing money.
It is believed the company to lose money.
The company is believed that it loses money.
exercises.answer: The company is believed to be losing money.
exercises.example_sentence: The company is believed to be losing money despite recent investments.

exercises.question: If I ___ speak French fluently, I would have translated that document for you yesterday.
exercises.answer: could
exercises.example_sentence: If I could speak French fluently, I would have translated that document for you yesterday.

exercises.question: Match the mixed conditional beginnings with their logical endings.
exercises.example_sentence: If I had eaten breakfast, I wouldn't be feeling so hungry now.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following sentence: 'It is reported that the CEO has resigned unexpectedly.'
exercises.answer: It is reported that the CEO has resigned unexpectedly.
exercises.example_sentence: It is reported that the CEO has resigned unexpectedly, causing market stress.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a present state affecting a past outcome.
exercises.answer: If I were rude I wouldn't have known him
exercises.example_sentence: If I were rude, I wouldn't have known him for so long.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: Everyone knows that she is a talented musician.
options: She is known to be a talented musician.
It is known her to be a musician.
She is known that she is a musician.
exercises.answer: She is known to be a talented musician.
exercises.example_sentence: She is known to be a talented musician by almost everyone in town.

exercises.question: It is ___ that the ancient ruins date back to the third century.
exercises.answer: estimated
exercises.example_sentence: It is estimated that the ancient ruins date back to the third century.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for this passive reporting structure.
exercises.answer: He is claimed to have stolen the money
exercises.example_sentence: He is claimed to have stolen the money despite his solid alibi.

exercises.question: Match the B2 verbs with their passive reporting counterparts.
exercises.example_sentence: It is alleged that the politician accepted bribes during the campaign.

exercises.question: Choose the correct mixed conditional: I didn't study, so I don't have my degree.
options: If I had studied, I would have my degree.
If I studied, I would have had my degree.
If I would have studied, I had my degree.
exercises.answer: If I had studied, I would have my degree.
exercises.example_sentence: If I had studied harder in college, I would have my degree now.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The new policy is understood to be a response to the recent crisis.'
exercises.answer: The new policy is understood to be a response to the recent crisis.
exercises.example_sentence: The new policy is understood to be a response to the recent crisis.

exercises.question: If you ___ more organized, you wouldn't have missed the flight yesterday.
exercises.answer: were
exercises.example_sentence: If you were more organized, you wouldn't have missed the flight yesterday.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a mixed conditional sentence.
exercises.answer: If she had won she would be rich
exercises.example_sentence: If she had won the lottery, she would be very rich now.

exercises.question: Match the conditional types with their functions.
exercises.example_sentence: Mixed conditionals allow us to connect different time periods in one sentence.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: They say the painting is a masterpiece.
options: The painting is said to be a masterpiece.
The painting says it is a masterpiece.
It says the painting is a masterpiece.
exercises.answer: The painting is said to be a masterpiece.
exercises.example_sentence: The painting is said to be a masterpiece by most art critics.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Had they known about the weather, they would be staying at home now.'
exercises.answer: Had they known about the weather, they would be staying at home now.
exercises.example_sentence: Had they known about the weather, they would be staying at home now.

exercises.question: By the time the conference starts, we ___ all the preparation for over three months.
exercises.answer: will have been doing
exercises.hint: Duration up to a future point.
exercises.example_sentence: By the time the conference starts, we will have been doing all the preparation for over three months.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: The mechanic is repairing Sarah's car right now.
options: Sarah is having her car repaired right now.
Sarah has repaired her car right now.
Sarah is getting to repair her car now.
exercises.answer: Sarah is having her car repaired right now.
exercises.example_sentence: Sarah is having her car repaired right now because the engine was making a strange noise.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a Future Perfect sentence.
exercises.answer: By Friday I will have finished the report
exercises.example_sentence: By Friday I will have finished the report, so we can discuss it then.

exercises.question: Match the future forms with their primary usage.

pairs.right: Action in progress at a time.
Someone does a task for you.

answer.right: Action in progress at a time.
Someone does a task for you.

exercises.example_sentence: Future forms help us specify exactly when an action occurs or finishes.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'This time next week, I will be lying on a beach in Spain.'
exercises.answer: This time next week, I will be lying on a beach in Spain.
exercises.example_sentence: This time next week, I will be lying on a beach in Spain, enjoying the sun.

exercises.question: I need to ___ my hair cut before the wedding next Saturday.
exercises.answer: get
exercises.example_sentence: I need to get my hair cut before the wedding next Saturday.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a causative structure.
exercises.answer: We had our house painted last month
exercises.example_sentence: We had our house painted last month to increase its market value.

exercises.question: Choose the correct future form: Don't call me at 8 PM because I ___ dinner.
exercises.answer: will be having
exercises.example_sentence: Don't call me at 8 PM because I will be having dinner with my family.

exercises.question: Match the objects with the common causative actions.
exercises.example_sentence: I need to have my eyes tested as I've been getting headaches recently.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They will have been living in London for a decade by next year.'
exercises.answer: They will have been living in London for a decade by next year.
exercises.example_sentence: They will have been living in London for a decade by next year.

exercises.question: Will you ___ using the car this afternoon? I need to go to the supermarket.
exercises.answer: be
exercises.example_sentence: Will you be using the car this afternoon? I need to go to the supermarket.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: Someone stole my passport while I was traveling.
options: I had my passport stolen while traveling.
I got to steal my passport while traveling.
My passport had stolen while I traveled.
exercises.answer: I had my passport stolen while traveling.
exercises.example_sentence: I had my passport stolen while traveling, which was a complete nightmare.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to ask about a future duration.
exercises.answer: How long will you have been working here
exercises.hint: Question form of Future Perfect Cont.
exercises.example_sentence: How long will you have been working here by the time you retire?

exercises.question: Match the causative verbs with their correct structures.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll get my brother to help us move the furniture on Sunday.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I'm going to have the kitchen renovated later this year.'
exercises.answer: I'm going to have the kitchen renovated later this year.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm going to have the kitchen renovated later this year to modernise it.

exercises.question: By 2030, scientists ___ a cure for this specific virus.
exercises.answer: will have found
exercises.example_sentence: By 2030, scientists will have found a cure for this specific virus.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence: We are having our lawn mowed.
options: A gardener is cutting the grass for us.
We are cutting the grass ourselves.
The lawn is cutting the grass.
exercises.answer: A gardener is cutting the grass for us.
exercises.example_sentence: We are having our lawn mowed by a local gardener every two weeks.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a Future Continuous plan.
exercises.answer: The directors will be meeting at ten
exercises.example_sentence: The directors will be meeting at ten o'clock tomorrow to discuss the budget.

exercises.question: I finally got my assistant ___ all the flights for the business trip.
exercises.answer: to book
exercises.example_sentence: I finally got my assistant to book all the flights for the business trip.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'He'll have been traveling for twenty-four hours by the time he arrives.'
exercises.answer: He'll have been traveling for twenty-four hours by the time he arrives.
exercises.example_sentence: He'll have been traveling for twenty-four hours by the time he arrives.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: I am certain that he forgot about the meeting.
options: He must have forgotten about the meeting.
He should have forgotten about the meeting.
He can't have forgotten about the meeting.
exercises.answer: He must have forgotten about the meeting.
exercises.example_sentence: He must have forgotten about the meeting, otherwise he would be here by now.

exercises.question: The laptop, ___ I bought only last month, is already making a strange noise.
exercises.answer: which
exercises.example_sentence: The laptop, which I bought only last month, is already making a strange noise.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a relative clause.
exercises.answer: The woman who lives next door is a doctor
exercises.example_sentence: The woman who lives next door is a doctor at the local hospital.

exercises.question: Match the relative pronouns with their appropriate usage.
exercises.example_sentence: That is the colleague whose brother works for NASA.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'She can't have been at home because I saw her at the gym.'
exercises.answer: She can't have been at home because I saw her at the gym.
exercises.example_sentence: She can't have been at home because I saw her at the gym an hour ago.

exercises.question: The man ___ car was stolen reported the incident to the police immediately.
exercises.answer: whose
exercises.example_sentence: The man whose car was stolen reported the incident to the police immediately.

exercises.question: Choose the correct deduction: It's possible that they missed the train.
options: They might have missed the train.
They must have missed the train.
They should have missed the train.
exercises.answer: They might have missed the train.
exercises.example_sentence: They might have missed the train, but let's wait another ten minutes.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a modal of deduction sentence.
exercises.answer: It must have been very expensive to buy
exercises.example_sentence: It must have been very expensive to buy such a large house in the city center.

exercises.question: Match the modal phrases with their level of certainty.
exercises.example_sentence: You can't have seen Peter today; he's on holiday in Japan!

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Brussels, which is the capital of Belgium, is a multicultural city.'
exercises.answer: Brussels, which is the capital of Belgium, is a multicultural city.
exercises.example_sentence: Brussels, which is the capital of Belgium, is a multicultural city.

exercises.question: Look at those clouds! It ___ rain later this afternoon.
exercises.answer: might
exercises.example_sentence: Look at those clouds! It might rain later this afternoon.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses a non-defining relative clause correctly?
options: My brother, who lives in Paris, is visiting.
The car that I bought is very fast.
The man who is standing there is my boss.
exercises.answer: My brother, who lives in Paris, is visiting.
exercises.example_sentence: My brother, who lives in Paris, is visiting us for Christmas this year.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to describe a person.
exercises.answer: That is the actor whom I met yesterday
exercises.example_sentence: That is the actor whom I met yesterday while I was at the cafe.

exercises.question: Match the situation to the deduction.
exercises.example_sentence: The lights are on, so he must be home from work already.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The restaurant where we had dinner was surprisingly affordable.'
exercises.answer: The restaurant where we had dinner was surprisingly affordable.
exercises.example_sentence: The restaurant where we had dinner was surprisingly affordable despite the location.

exercises.question: He ___ be exhausted after running a full marathon this morning.
exercises.answer: must
exercises.example_sentence: He must be exhausted after running a full marathon this morning.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence: (Defining relative clause)
options: The book that I am reading is fascinating.
The book, that I am reading, is fascinating.
The book which, I am reading, is fascinating.
exercises.answer: The book that I am reading is fascinating.
exercises.example_sentence: The book that I am reading is fascinating and very well written.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a negative deduction.
exercises.answer: She couldn't have stolen the money honestly
exercises.example_sentence: She couldn't have stolen the money honestly; she was with me all day.

exercises.question: That's the reason ___ I decided to leave the company.
exercises.answer: why
exercises.example_sentence: That's the reason why I decided to leave the company and start my own business.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The students whose grades improve will receive a certificate.'
exercises.answer: The students whose grades improve will receive a certificate.
exercises.example_sentence: The students whose grades improve significantly will receive a certificate of achievement.

exercises.question: The more you practice your English, ___ confident you will become during the exam.
exercises.answer: the more
exercises.example_sentence: The more you practice your English, the more confident you will become during the exam.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a regret about a past situation.
exercises.answer: If only I had studied harder at university
exercises.example_sentence: If only I had studied harder at university, I might have found a better job.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: Living in the city is much more expensive than the countryside.
options: The countryside is far less expensive than the city.
The city is as expensive as the countryside.
The countryside is more expensive than the city.
exercises.answer: The countryside is far less expensive than the city.
exercises.example_sentence: The countryside is far less expensive than the city, though there are fewer jobs.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I wish it would stop raining so we could go for a walk in the park.'
exercises.answer: I wish it would stop raining so we could go for a walk in the park.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish it would stop raining so we could go for a walk in the park.

exercises.question: Match the 'wish' structures with their correct functions.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I had taken that opportunity when it was offered to me.

exercises.question: This smartphone is ___ as powerful as the previous model, despite being cheaper.
exercises.answer: every bit
exercises.example_sentence: This smartphone is every bit as powerful as the previous model, despite being cheaper.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses annoyance with a current habit?
options: I wish you wouldn't leave your shoes in the hallway.
I wish I hadn't left my shoes in the hallway.
I wish I were leaving my shoes in the hallway.
exercises.answer: I wish you wouldn't leave your shoes in the hallway.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you wouldn't leave your shoes in the hallway; it's very messy.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a complex comparative sentence.
exercises.answer: The higher the demand the price becomes the
exercises.example_sentence: The higher the demand, the higher the price becomes in a free market.

exercises.question: If only we ___ more time to finish the project before the deadline.
exercises.answer: had
exercises.example_sentence: If only we had more time to finish the project before the deadline.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The movie was nowhere near as good as the book I read last summer.'
exercises.answer: The movie was nowhere near as good as the book I read last summer.
exercises.example_sentence: The movie was nowhere near as good as the book I read last summer.

exercises.question: Match the intensifiers with their comparative structures.
exercises.example_sentence: This version is slightly better than the one we tested last week.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence for a present wish: I don't speak German.
options: I wish I would speak German.
I wish I have spoken German.
exercises.answer: I wish I spoke German.
exercises.hint: Use past simple for present wish.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I spoke German so I could communicate with our clients in Berlin.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to compare two things using 'not nearly'.
exercises.answer: This one is not nearly as comfortable as that
exercises.example_sentence: This one is not nearly as comfortable as that old sofa we had.

exercises.question: He is getting ___ and richer every year thanks to his investments.
exercises.answer: richer
exercises.example_sentence: He is getting richer and richer every year thanks to his successful investments.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I wish I hadn't eaten that third piece of chocolate cake.'
exercises.answer: I wish I hadn't eaten that third piece of chocolate cake.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I hadn't eaten that third piece of chocolate cake; I feel sick now.

exercises.question: Match the beginning to the end to form logical comparisons.
exercises.example_sentence: The sooner we leave for the airport, the earlier we will arrive.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a wish for someone else.
exercises.answer: I wish you would be a bit more quiet
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you would be a bit more quiet while I am on the phone.

exercises.question: Choose the most formal comparison.
options: The result was significantly better than expected.
The result was way better than expected.
The result was a lot more good than expected.
exercises.answer: The result was significantly better than expected.
exercises.example_sentence: The result was significantly better than expected despite the budget cuts.

exercises.question: I'd rather you ___ tell anyone what I just said to you.
exercises.answer: didn't
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you didn't tell anyone what I just said to you, it's a secret.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'If only I had known about the traffic, I would have taken the train.'
exercises.answer: If only I had known about the traffic, I would have taken the train.
exercises.example_sentence: If only I had known about the traffic, I would have taken the train instead.

exercises.question: Never ___ I seen such a breathtaking view in all my years of traveling.
exercises.answer: have
exercises.example_sentence: Never have I seen such a breathtaking view in all my years of traveling.

exercises.question: Choose the correct meaning: 'He stopped to smoke.'
options: He paused his activity in order to have a cigarette.
He quit the habit of smoking permanently.
He was smoking while he was walking.
exercises.answer: He paused his activity in order to have a cigarette.
exercises.example_sentence: He was driving for hours, so he stopped to smoke and stretch his legs.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to create a formal inversion.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances should this door be opened
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should this door be opened without proper authorization.

exercises.question: Match the verbs with their required form (Gerund or Infinitive).
exercises.example_sentence: I simply cannot afford to buy a new car this year.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Seldom do we encounter such dedication in the workplace these days.'
exercises.answer: Seldom do we encounter such dedication in the workplace these days.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom do we encounter such dedication in the workplace these days.

exercises.question: I remember ___ the lights off, but the house was bright when I returned.
exercises.answer: switching
exercises.example_sentence: I distinctly remember switching the lights off before I left the house.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses inversion correctly?
options: Not only was the food cold, but the service was also slow.
Not only the food was cold, but also the service slow.
Not only food being cold, the service was slow.
exercises.answer: Not only was the food cold, but the service was also slow.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only was the food cold, but the service was also incredibly slow.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a failed attempt.
exercises.answer: I tried to open the window but it was stuck
exercises.example_sentence: I tried to open the window, but it was completely stuck.

exercises.question: Match the inverted phrases with their meanings.

pairs.right: He arrived and then it happened.

answer.right: He arrived and then it happened.

exercises.example_sentence: Little did they know that the surprise party was already ruined.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I regret to inform you that your application has been unsuccessful.'
exercises.answer: I regret to inform you that your application has been unsuccessful.
exercises.example_sentence: I regret to inform you that your application has been unsuccessful on this occasion.

exercises.question: If the stain doesn't come out, try ___ some vinegar on it.
exercises.answer: rubbing
exercises.example_sentence: If the stain doesn't come out, try rubbing some vinegar on it.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'We are looking forward to ___ you at the gala.'
exercises.answer: seeing
exercises.example_sentence: We are looking forward to seeing you at the gala next weekend.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past regret.
exercises.answer: I regret not studying harder when I was younger
exercises.example_sentence: I regret not studying harder when I was younger and had the time.

exercises.question: Match the verb + preposition with the gerund.
exercises.example_sentence: She insisted on paying the bill despite my protests.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'No sooner had the sun risen than the birds began to sing.'
exercises.answer: No sooner had the sun risen than the birds began to sing.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had the sun risen than the birds began to sing.

exercises.question: The boss made us ___ late to finish the quarterly report.
exercises.answer: stay
exercises.example_sentence: The boss made us stay late to finish the quarterly report.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence: 'It's no use...'
options: It's no use crying over spilt milk.
It's no use to cry over spilt milk.
It's no use cry over spilt milk.
exercises.answer: It's no use crying over spilt milk.
exercises.example_sentence: It's no use crying over spilt milk; we just need to find a solution.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal restriction.
exercises.answer: Little did I know that the meeting was cancelled
exercises.example_sentence: Little did I know that the meeting was cancelled before I arrived.

exercises.question: Scarcely ___ the match started when it began to rain heavily.
exercises.answer: had
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had the match started when it began to rain heavily.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Hardly had I opened the door when the phone rang.'
exercises.answer: Hardly had I opened the door when the phone rang.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had I opened the door when the phone rang.

exercises.question: ___ the heavy rain, the outdoor concert continued until midnight.
exercises.answer: Despite
exercises.example_sentence: Despite the heavy rain, the outdoor concert continued until midnight.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: They are going to renovate the old town hall.
options: The old town hall is going to be renovated.
The old town hall is being renovated.
The old town hall will have renovated.
exercises.answer: The old town hall is going to be renovated.
exercises.example_sentence: The old town hall is going to be renovated to serve as a community center.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a contrast connector.
exercises.answer: She worked hard nevertheless she failed the exam
exercises.example_sentence: She worked extremely hard; nevertheless, she failed the exam by two points.

exercises.question: Match the conjunctions with their grammatical requirements.
exercises.example_sentence: Even though it was late, he decided to finish the report.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The witness is reported to have been given police protection.'
exercises.answer: The witness is reported to have been given police protection.
exercises.example_sentence: The witness is reported to have been given police protection after the trial.

exercises.question: I hate ___ told what to do when I am trying to concentrate.
exercises.answer: being
exercises.example_sentence: I hate being told what to do when I am trying to concentrate on my work.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence: (Contrast)
options: I love tea, whereas my brother prefers coffee.
I love tea, despite my brother prefers coffee.
I love tea, however my brother prefers coffee.
exercises.answer: I love tea, whereas my brother prefers coffee.
exercises.example_sentence: I love drinking tea, whereas my brother prefers a strong cup of coffee.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a causative passive structure.
exercises.answer: He had his nose broken in the fight
exercises.example_sentence: He had his nose broken in the fight, which was very painful.

exercises.question: Match the passive voice usage with the context.
exercises.example_sentence: The new software is currently being tested by our developers.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Provided that you finish your chores, you can go out tonight.'
exercises.answer: Provided that you finish your chores, you can go out tonight.
exercises.example_sentence: Provided that you finish your chores, you can go out with your friends.

exercises.question: The suspect is believed ___ the country using a fake passport.
exercises.answer: to have left
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect is believed to have left the country using a fake passport.

exercises.question: Choose the most appropriate connector: We stayed inside ___ the storm.
exercises.answer: owing to
exercises.example_sentence: We stayed inside owing to the storm that was raging outside.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about expectations.
exercises.answer: The guests are expected to arrive at six
exercises.example_sentence: The guests are expected to arrive at six o'clock this evening.

exercises.question: Match the connectors with their synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The weather was poor; consequently, the flight was delayed.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Nevertheless, the team decided to continue with the original plan.'
exercises.answer: Nevertheless, the team decided to continue with the original plan.
exercises.example_sentence: Nevertheless, the team decided to continue with the original plan.

exercises.question: The package needs ___ before it is sent to the customer.
exercises.answer: checking
exercises.example_sentence: The package needs checking before it is sent to the customer.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses a condition correctly?
options: I will come as long as I don't have to drive.
I will come although I don't have to drive.
I will come so that I don't have to drive.
exercises.answer: I will come as long as I don't have to drive.
exercises.example_sentence: I will come to the party as long as I don't have to drive home late.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a passive infinitive structure.
exercises.answer: There is still a lot to be done
exercises.example_sentence: There is still a lot to be done before the grand opening next month.

exercises.question: The computer system crashed, ___ causing a delay in production.
exercises.answer: thereby
exercises.example_sentence: The computer system crashed, thereby causing a significant delay in production.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'In spite of the difficulties, the project was a resounding success.'
exercises.answer: In spite of the difficulties, the project was a resounding success.
exercises.example_sentence: In spite of the difficulties, the project was a resounding success.

exercises.question: Choose the correct reporting verb: 'I didn't break the vase!'
options: He refused to break the vase.
exercises.answer: He denied breaking the vase.
exercises.example_sentence: He denied breaking the vase despite the fact that he was alone in the room.

exercises.question: You ___ have told me you were coming; I would have prepared some food.
exercises.answer: should
exercises.example_sentence: You should have told me you were coming; I would have prepared some dinner.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a reported recommendation.
exercises.answer: He recommended that we visit the museum early
exercises.example_sentence: He recommended that we visit the museum early to avoid the long queues.

exercises.question: Match the reporting verb with the correct following structure.
exercises.example_sentence: He apologized for being late, explaining that the traffic was unusually heavy.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They needn't have brought umbrellas as the weather turned out to be beautiful.'
exercises.answer: They needn't have brought umbrellas as the weather turned out to be beautiful.
exercises.example_sentence: They needn't have brought umbrellas as the weather turned out to be beautiful.

exercises.question: The doctor advised me ___ more exercise to improve my cardiovascular health.
exercises.answer: to take
exercises.example_sentence: The doctor advised me to take more exercise to improve my cardiovascular health.

exercises.question: Choose the correct deduction: 'I'm sure she was happy when she won.'
options: She must have been happy when she won.
She could have been happy when she won.
She should have been happy when she won.
exercises.answer: She must have been happy when she won.
exercises.example_sentence: She must have been happy when she won the award after so much effort.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about unnecessary past actions.
exercises.answer: You didn't need to buy milk yesterday
exercises.hint: It wasn't necessary (and maybe you didn't).
exercises.example_sentence: You didn't need to buy milk yesterday as we already had three bottles.

exercises.question: Match the modal verb with its function.
exercises.example_sentence: We may as well start the meeting since everyone is already here.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The manager accused him of leaking confidential information to the press.'
exercises.answer: The manager accused him of leaking confidential information to the press.
exercises.example_sentence: The manager accused him of leaking confidential information to the press.

exercises.question: If you are feeling unwell, you ___ to see a doctor immediately.
exercises.answer: ought
exercises.example_sentence: If you are feeling unwell, you ought to see a doctor immediately.

exercises.question: Choose the correct reported question: 'Where did you go last night?' she asked.
options: She asked me where I had gone the night before.
She asked me where did I go the night before.
She asked me where I went last night.
exercises.answer: She asked me where I had gone the night before.
exercises.example_sentence: She asked me where I had gone the night before because she was worried.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express an apology.
exercises.answer: The staff apologized for being late for the meeting
exercises.example_sentence: The staff apologized for being late for the meeting due to the train strike.

exercises.question: Match the direct speech to its reported summary.
exercises.example_sentence: He refused to do it despite my repeated requests for help.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'She suggested going to the cinema instead of staying at home.'
exercises.answer: She suggested going to the cinema instead of staying at home.
exercises.example_sentence: She suggested going to the cinema instead of staying at home on a Friday night.

exercises.question: He ___ have been exhausted after working a double shift at the hospital.
exercises.answer: must
exercises.example_sentence: He must have been exhausted after working a double shift at the hospital.

exercises.question: Choose the correct reporting structure: 'Don't forget the tickets!'
options: She reminded me to take the tickets.
She suggested to take the tickets.
She explained me to take the tickets.
exercises.answer: She reminded me to take the tickets.
exercises.example_sentence: She reminded me to take the tickets before we left for the airport.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about past ability.
exercises.answer: I could have won the race had I trained harder
exercises.example_sentence: I could have won the race had I trained harder during the summer.

exercises.question: I ___ rather you didn't smoke in the house, if you don't mind.
exercises.answer: would
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather you didn't smoke in the house, if you don't mind.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They offered to give us a lift to the station in their new car.'
exercises.answer: They offered to give us a lift to the station in their new car.
exercises.example_sentence: They offered to give us a lift to the station in their new car.

exercises.question: ___ all the tickets, the organizers decided to add an extra show.
exercises.answer: Having sold
exercises.example_sentence: Having sold all the tickets, the organizers decided to add an extra show for the fans.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: It is late and the children should go to bed now.
options: It's high time the children went to bed.
It's high time the children go to bed.
It's high time the children have gone to bed.
exercises.answer: It's high time the children went to bed.
exercises.example_sentence: It's high time the children went to bed as they have school early tomorrow.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a participle clause.
exercises.answer: Feeling exhausted after the marathon she went to bed early
exercises.example_sentence: Feeling exhausted after the marathon, she went to bed early to recover.

exercises.question: Match the hypothetical structures with their correct verb patterns.
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you didn't tell him about the surprise until tomorrow morning.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Not wanting to wake the baby, she crept quietly into the room.'
exercises.answer: Not wanting to wake the baby, she crept quietly into the room.
exercises.example_sentence: Not wanting to wake the baby, she crept quietly into the room to get her bag.

exercises.question: I'd rather ___ out tonight; I'm feeling quite tired.
exercises.answer: not go
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather not go out tonight as I have a lot of work to finish.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses a participle clause correctly?
options: Opened in 1920, the hotel is famous for its style.
Opening in 1920, the hotel is famous for its style.
Being opened in 1920, the hotel is famous for its style.
exercises.answer: Opened in 1920, the hotel is famous for its style.
exercises.example_sentence: Opened in 1920, the hotel is famous for its unique architectural style.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a hypothetical situation.
exercises.answer: Suppose they offered you the job what if
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose they offered you the job, would you be willing to move to Asia?

exercises.question: Match the participle clause beginnings with their completions.

pairs.right: he had to call a locksmith.

answer.right: he had to call a locksmith.

exercises.example_sentence: Having lost the key, he had to call a locksmith to get into his apartment.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Suppose you were given a million dollars, how would you spend it?'
exercises.answer: Suppose you were given a million dollars, how would you spend it?
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose you were given a million dollars, how would you spend it?

exercises.question: ___ by the beautiful scenery, we decided to stop and take some photos.
exercises.answer: Amazed
exercises.example_sentence: Amazed by the beautiful scenery, we decided to stop and take some photos.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'I'd rather you ___ your phone during the movie.'
exercises.answer: didn't use
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you didn't use your phone during the movie; it's very distracting.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a long-overdue action.
exercises.answer: It is high time we redecorated the living room
exercises.example_sentence: It is high time we redecorated the living room; the wallpaper is peeling.

exercises.question: Match the clauses to create logical sentences.
exercises.example_sentence: Not knowing the way to the restaurant, I used the GPS on my phone.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Having lived in Tokyo for five years, he speaks Japanese fluently.'
exercises.answer: Having lived in Tokyo for five years, he speaks Japanese fluently.
exercises.example_sentence: Having lived in Tokyo for five years, he speaks Japanese fluently.

exercises.question: Suppose we ___ the house, where would we go then?
exercises.answer: sold
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose we sold the house, where would we live then?

exercises.question: What is the meaning of: 'Walking through the park, I found a wallet.'
options: While I was walking, I found a wallet.
Because I walked, I found a wallet.
After I had walked, I found a wallet.
exercises.answer: While I was walking, I found a wallet.
exercises.example_sentence: Walking through the park this morning, I found a leather wallet on the grass.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a preference for someone else.
exercises.answer: I would rather you stayed at home tonight
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather you stayed at home tonight instead of going to that party.

exercises.question: ___ the book twice, I still couldn't understand the ending.
exercises.answer: Having read
exercises.example_sentence: Having read the book twice already, I still couldn't understand the complex ending.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Its about time you started taking your studies seriously.'
exercises.answer: Its about time you started taking your studies seriously.
exercises.example_sentence: Its about time you started taking your studies seriously if you want to pass.

exercises.question: The government is committed to protecting ___ environment for future generations.
exercises.answer: the
exercises.example_sentence: The government is committed to protecting the environment for future generations.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses articles correctly for abstract concepts?
options: Happiness is more important than the money.
The happiness is more important than money.
Happiness is more important than money.
exercises.answer: Happiness is more important than money.
exercises.example_sentence: In many cultures, happiness is considered more important than money.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to describe a specific location.
exercises.answer: The university is located in the city center
exercises.example_sentence: The university is located in the city center, making it easily accessible.

exercises.question: Match the noun types with their typical article usage.
exercises.example_sentence: The Alps are beautiful, but climbing Mount Everest is a different challenge.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I usually go to work by bus, but today I took the train.'
exercises.answer: I usually go to work by bus, but today I took the train.
exercises.example_sentence: I usually go to work by bus, but today I took the train instead.

exercises.question: We are meeting ___ the end of the month to discuss the new budget.
exercises.answer: at
exercises.example_sentence: We are meeting at the end of the month to discuss the new budget.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'She went to ___ to study architecture.'
exercises.answer: university
exercises.example_sentence: She went to university to study architecture and graduated last year.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a time-based expression.
exercises.answer: They have been living here for a decade
exercises.example_sentence: They have been living here for a decade and know the area well.

exercises.question: Match the prepositions with the correct time phrases.
exercises.example_sentence: We met on Tuesday morning to watch the sunrise at the beach.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Technology has had a huge impact on the way we communicate.'
exercises.answer: Technology has had a huge impact on the way we communicate.
exercises.example_sentence: Technology has had a huge impact on the way we communicate globally.

exercises.question: The CEO is currently ___ a business trip in Southeast Asia.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO is currently on a business trip in Southeast Asia.

exercises.question: Which article is needed? 'He is ___ honest man.'
exercises.answer: an
exercises.example_sentence: He is an honest man who always keeps his promises.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to describe an office location.
exercises.answer: My office is located on the second floor
exercises.example_sentence: My office is located on the second floor, right next to the elevator.

exercises.question: Match the activity with the correct preposition of place.
exercises.example_sentence: He spent all day sitting at a desk and is now standing in a queue for the bus.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'In the 1990s, the Internet became available to the general public.'
exercises.answer: In the 1990s, the Internet became available to the general public.
exercises.example_sentence: In the 1990s, the Internet became available to the general public.

exercises.question: I'll see you ___ Monday afternoon for our weekly review.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.example_sentence: I'll see you on Monday afternoon for our weekly review.

exercises.question: Choose the correct article for the title: '___ President of the United States.'
exercises.answer: The
exercises.example_sentence: The President of the United States is visiting the capital tomorrow.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a general fact.
exercises.answer: Water is considered a valuable resource
exercises.example_sentence: Water is considered a valuable resource in arid regions.

exercises.question: We arrived at the theater just ___ time to see the opening scene.
exercises.answer: in
exercises.example_sentence: We arrived at the theater just in time to see the opening scene.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The Nile is the longest river in the world, stretching through Africa.'
exercises.answer: The Nile is the longest river in the world, stretching through Africa.
exercises.example_sentence: The Nile is the longest river in the world, stretching through Africa.

exercises.question: If I ___ harder at school, I would have a better job now.
exercises.answer: had studied
exercises.example_sentence: If I had studied harder at school, I would have a better job now.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a mixed conditional?
options: If he hadn't missed the bus, he would be here by now.
If he misses the bus, he will be late.
If he had missed the bus, he would have been late.
exercises.answer: If he hadn't missed the bus, he would be here by now.
exercises.example_sentence: If he hadn't missed the bus, he would be here by now, sitting with us.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a phrasal verb sentence.
exercises.answer: I ran across an old friend at the supermarket
exercises.example_sentence: I ran across an old friend at the supermarket yesterday morning.

exercises.question: Match the mixed conditional types with their meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: If I were more organized (present trait), I wouldn't have lost my keys (past).

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'If she hadn't taken the job, she wouldn't be living in London now.'
exercises.answer: If she hadn't taken the job, she wouldn't be living in London now.
exercises.example_sentence: If she hadn't taken the job, she wouldn't be living in London now.

exercises.question: We need to ___ a solution to this problem before the deadline tomorrow.
exercises.answer: come up with
exercises.hint: Meaning: to think of an idea.
exercises.example_sentence: We need to come up with a solution to this problem before the deadline tomorrow.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'If I ___ afraid of spiders, I would have picked it up.'
exercises.answer: weren't
exercises.example_sentence: If I weren't afraid of spiders, I would have picked it up and put it outside.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'look forward to'.
exercises.answer: I am looking forward to starting my new job
exercises.example_sentence: I am looking forward to starting my new job next Monday.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verbs with their definitions.
exercises.example_sentence: They had to call off the meeting because the manager was ill.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'If I had known you were in town, we could go for a coffee today.'
exercises.answer: If I had known you were in town, we could go for a coffee today.
exercises.example_sentence: If I had known you were in town, we could go for a coffee today.

exercises.question: He's really ___ the fact that he won the championship last week.
exercises.answer: made up about
exercises.example_sentence: He's really made up about the fact that he won the championship last week.

exercises.question: Which mixed conditional makes sense? (Past fact vs present trait)
options: If I hadn't won the lottery, I wouldn't be rich now.
If I wouldn't have won, I am not rich.
If I didn't win, I wouldn't have been rich.
exercises.answer: If I hadn't won the lottery, I wouldn't be rich now.
exercises.example_sentence: If I hadn't won the lottery, I wouldn't be rich now; I'd still be working.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'break down'.
exercises.answer: The car broke down on the way to work
exercises.example_sentence: The car broke down on the way to work, so I was late for the presentation.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verbs with 'get'.
exercises.example_sentence: It took him a long time to get over the flu.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I can't put up with that constant noise from the construction site anymore.'
exercises.answer: I can't put up with that constant noise from the construction site anymore.
exercises.example_sentence: I can't put up with that constant noise from the construction site anymore.

exercises.question: If you ___ me earlier, I wouldn't have to stay late tonight.
exercises.answer: had told
exercises.example_sentence: If you had told me earlier, I wouldn't have to stay late tonight to finish this.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrasal verb: 'I need to ___ the meaning of this word.'
exercises.answer: look up
exercises.example_sentence: I need to look up the meaning of this word in the dictionary.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a mixed conditional.
exercises.answer: If I were not tired I would have gone out last night
exercises.example_sentence: If I were not so tired generally, I would have gone out with you last night.

exercises.question: She's always ___ new excuses for why she's late to the office.
exercises.answer: making up
exercises.example_sentence: She's always making up new excuses for why she's late to the office.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The meeting was called off due to the unexpected train strike.'
exercises.answer: The meeting was called off due to the unexpected train strike.
exercises.example_sentence: The meeting was called off due to the unexpected train strike.
